sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.p: Something younger than Sir Dottrell, my Twenty-two a little ſhort of his Ninety-two.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Do you know where you are, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.p: In the preſence of a Father.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Then where's your Reſpect and Duty?—

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.p: Paid to your Character and Virtues; not to your Weakneſs and Injuſtice. In ſhort, Sir, this Sir Dottrell—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Is the Man of the VVorld—

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.p: Shall never be my Brother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: He ſhan't!

sp.speaker: Ned. St.
sp.p: No, ſhall not!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: How, Bully, do you come to bid Defiance to me,
To give me Battle? Ha!

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.l: If Prayers and Tears
Are Battling Weapons, Sir, I come all arm'd againſt you:
I do beſeech you, Sir, let Nature, Pity,
Juſtice, Humanity, all plead againſt this unequal Match.
Look on my Siſters Youth, her Virgin Bloom,
VVorthy a warmer Bed than ſuch a Sepulchre:
Nay, Sir, if I may boaſt her Charms, her ſtock
Of Beauty—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Is a Match for Sir Dottrel, Boy;
Beauty to Beauty, Son; his Gold and her Eyes,
They'll ſparkle together, Boy: He a fair Eſtate,
And ſhe the fair Miſtreſs of it: Nothing better match'd, Ned.

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.l: Match'd with a Vengeance! Yes, her Youth, and Sweets, and Charms,
To his Gout, and Cramps, and Palſies! Marry her! Bury her.
Her Bed! Her Grave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Hold, Sir, a word with you;
Confeſs, and tell me true: Is this whole Outcry
Only againſt Sir Dottrel? Not one Puff
Of all this Storm for your dear Darling Palmarin?

sp.speaker: Stan.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, if Truth muſt ſpeak, I am a Champion
For that deſerving Youth, that ſuffering Virtue,
Worthier my Siſters Heart in all his Ruines,
Then his vile Rival in his Chain of Gold.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Ay, now 'tis plain. O thou ungracious Boy!
An Advocate for Rags, and Shame, and Poverty.

sp.speaker: N. Stan.
sp.p: For Worth, and Truth, and Honour.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Honour and Beggary! A black Swan and a white Crow.
Such another VVord,
And, by all the Vengeance of an Angry Father,
I'll diſinherit thee.

sp.speaker: N. Stan.
sp.l: As you pleaſe, Sir;
Your Son and your Eſtate are both your own.
But let me tell you, Sir, 'tis not th' Inheritance
Of Twenty Patrimonies ſhall frighten me from Juſtice▪
Or ſhrink one Nerve in the great Cauſe of Truth.
Look ye, Sir; I can be a Martyr to Honour, but not a
Cully to Fear.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Well, thou'rt brave my Boy. But come, Ned;
Let you and I make a Drawn Battle between us.
Your Siſter and I will e'en take it by Turns:
sp.p: I'll diſpoſe of her whilſt ſhe's mine, and ſhe ſhall diſpoſe of her ſelf when ſhe's her own. I'll marry Jacintha to Old Sir Dottrel, and ſhe ſhall marry Sir Dottrel's Widow to young Palmerin. For, look ye, Son; one Month of Matrimony will wheedle her into his whole Eſtate; three Months of Family-Duty break the Old Fellow's Heart; Six Months of Mourning ſerve for the Widowhood; and ſo Nine Months of Patience gets your Young Palmarin a Wife with 5000 l. a Year, to troll, ſhine, and roar with, dear Boy; worth twenty blind beggarly Bargains, to get Brats and ſtarve with.

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.l: Nay, fie, this ſhameful Argument—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: I'll hear no more. Get you home to your Temple, read your Littleton, eat your Mutton, draggle ye • r Goon, and come again (let me ſee) to morow Night. By that time I ſhall have conſider'd matters, and will give you full Satisfaction in the Point.

sp.speaker: Ned St.
sp.l: On that Condition, Sir, I'm all Obedience:
I'll take my Leave, and wait your Hour of Grace▪ Exit.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Yes, Son, I'll marry her in the morning, and give thee Satisfaction at Night.

lg.l: Young Counſellours Old Heads must never ſway;
Gold in a Fathers Scales must only weigh;
Let Sons Preach Honour, Int'rest is our Play▪ Exit.

div.stage: The SCENE, An Arborage of Palms and Lawrels, conſiſting of Nine Arches, environ'd with Flotoons of Flowers, bound with Ribbons of Gold, and held up with Flying Cupids.
Enter Sir Dottrel, met by Jacintha led by Shackarel.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: WEll, Sir Dottrel, here's honeſt Shackarell has told me your whole Mind; that you are reſolved to marry Jacintha, right or wrong; to take her as blind Men do Money, falſe or true, Braſs or Silver.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And if thou haſt the Conſcience to cheat that Blind Man with Adulterate for Sterling, be the Sin at thy own Door.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And then you dare venture upon me?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Dare! I muſt dare; for I can't live without thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Say you ſo, my Heart of Steel. Then let not your Noble Courage be caſt down: For to chear up your Heart, know, to the utter Confuſion of Fears and Jealouſies, I am Virtuous.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Virtuous!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And will live and die ſo;
Nay, all the Affronts and Cheats I've put upon you
Have been only ſo many Trials of your Patience and your Conſtancy;
And here, before honeſt Shakarell, I promiſe you,
Sir Dottrel is the Man of the whole World
Shall make me th' happieſt and beſt Wife in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I am tranſported!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, my whole laſt Night's Roguery—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh! No more of that.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Was all but a Sham-Plot.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! A Sham-Plot?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Betwixt your Man and me.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: My Man Shakarell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh! I'll be kinder than the Flower o'th' Sun,
Throw open all my Boſom and my Charms
To thy warm Joys.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: My Life, my Soul, my Heaven! Imitating their last Scene.
What think you now, Sir Dottrell?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: and was it you, ye young Rogue!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Even I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: But hadſt thou the Heart to put thy poor Maſter into that wicked Fright!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: All my young Miſtreſs's Deſign; ſhe drew me into the Plot, and I had not the Power to refuſe a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: No, you young Smirker! Well, I am the happieſt old Toaſt in three Kingdoms: Such a Wife, and ſuch a Servant; there are not the Fellows of 'em in the whole Town, from one End to th' other; Uds bud, not from Knaves-Acre to Cuckolds-Point.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And now, to ſhew you, Sir, how much I reliſh▪
The welcome Joys of being a happy Bride,
I have prepar'd a Bridal Entertainment;
A Marriage-Maſque, Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! A Maſque!

div.head: The Ceremony of a Nuptial Entertainment perform'd. Mrs. Croſs the Bride, and Mr. Leveridge the Bridegroom.
div.byline: The Muſick ſet by Mr. D. Purcel.

lg.l: The Nymphs of the Plain,
And Swains of the Grove
All the whole Noble Train
Of Smiling Love:
A Jolly Jolly Troop in all our Pride,
Our happy Joys we'll ſummon;
To day we have made a Maid a Bride,
And to Night we ſhall make a Woman▪
Let the Bluſhing Miſs,
That ſteals to the Bliſs,
Take a whole Load of Shame upon her:
All the true Joys of Life
Are i'th' Arms of a Wife,
In Love's fair Bed of Honour.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p: All the true Joys, &c.

sp.l: So now we have done the Work of the Day,
For the Work of the Night come all Hands away,
To lay the ſweet Bride,
By her Bridegroom's Side:
To Bed, to Bed with the Bride.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: Come, come, my dear Love, my Soul's all o' fire;
All burning Deſire,
In thy Arms to expire;
To drink the ſweet Nectar of Gods in Kiſſes,
And taſte their whole Heav'n in Bliſſes.
Then come, come, come away.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Oh, What ſhall I do!

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Come, come, come away.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Oh, How ſhall I go to a Man, to Bed!
I vow, I ſhall bluſh all Scarlet Red.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: Prethee, prethee, buſh
All Thoughts of a Bluſh.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Nay, fye, naughty Man; what is't that you want?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.l: All the warm ſweet Bleſſings that Love can grant.
Then come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I can't, I can't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Indeed, but you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I vow, but I ſha'n't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: You must, you ſhall.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I wont, I can't.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: But come, come to Bed.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: I ſhall die with Shame.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom.
sp.l: Come, come, come away, and caſt away Sorrow;
If thou bluſheſt to night, thou wilt ſmile tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Oh, let me but lie one Night more alone.

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: Not one Night more a Maid!

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Not one.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Well, well; if I must, I'll try what I can.
But what ſhall I do to lie by a Man▪
You'll put out the Candle?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And ſhut the Door?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: Ay, ay, ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And ſhall no body ſee?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, no body ſee.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.p: And no body hear?

sp.speaker: Bridegroom,
sp.p: No, none but we.

sp.speaker: Bride,
sp.l: Well, well; if I must, I'll try what I can.
But, what ſhall I do to lie by a Man!

sp.speaker: Chorus,
sp.l: All the true Joys of Life, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: I profeſs a moſt delicate Entertainment. But methinks that young Harlotry that peviſh Tit of a Bride was a little too Coy when ſhe ſhould go to Bed. I hope, my Dear, thou wilt not ſerve me ſo.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, no, no.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Then come along my little Honey-ſuckle.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Hold, Stay, Sir Dottrell. — Sir, before I marry, I have a requeſt which you muſt not deny me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Deny thee, Child! I can deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Then you muſt know I have made a ſolemn Vow never to marry that Man but he that ſhall ſteal me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Steal thee!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, and this, Sir, you muſt promiſe me, I muſt confeſs 'twas a raſh haſty Vow; but Vows when they are once made, are Sacred Things; and ſhould I break them, Heaven would never bleſs me.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: But why muſt I ſteal thee?

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Oh fie, Sir Dottrell, what ſhrink at ſo ſmall a piece of Knight Errantry, to win a Fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Beſides, Sir Dottrell, I'll make it very eaſie; you Sir Dottrell, and your Man Shackarell ſhall come with a Ladder, to our Back-window, exactly at Twelve a Clock at Night. I'll ſteal the Keys of the Window, be ready to receive you, run into your Arms, trundle down the Ladder with you, knock up the Parſon, ſlip into the Church, tumble o're the Matrimony, troll home
to my Father, tell him the whole ſtory of the Frolick, whilſt you ſing He ſmiles, I laugh, and all the Bells of the Town ring Oh be Joyful.

sp.speaker: Sir D.
sp.p: Huzzah! why I'll do't; ſay no more, I'll do't. Steal thee! why I'll ſteal thee all; ſteal thy heart, ſteal to Bed to thee; ſteal into thy Boſom, ſteal into thy—Oh ſuch Raptures! ſuch Delight! How ſhall I contain me to the Wedding-night.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter Sir Dottrell with a Dark Lanthorn, and Palmarin with a Ladder, which he ſets up to the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: See, Sir Dottrell, ſee, the Windows unlockt, the Cloud's opening▪ and your Dear Angel ready for deſcending. O you're a happy Man, Sir. But come aloft, Sir, mount the Walls, and Scale the Battlements.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: But I don't like this Night-work.—But be ſure you hold the Ladder faſt, for if it ſhould ſlip, I ſhould fall very heavy, for five thouſand a year's a great weight, Shackarell!

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Pox on you! you are one thouſand a year heavier of my Money.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: [Upon the Balcone.] Now, Sirrah, ſtay you there, and watch till I come down again.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Ay faith; I ſhall watch you!—Hſt, where are you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Here, Sir.
Enter a Boy with a Bellman's Habit, Lanthorn, &c. Palmerin dreſſes himſelf as a Bellman.
Exit Boy.

sp.speaker: Pal.

l.hi: All you that on your Beds lye waking,
To keep your Gity-brows from aking.
Firſt watch your Wives, and then your Money;
And drive the Hornets from your Honey.
For fear your Spouſe your Crabs inoculate,

sp.l: Keep her from Beaus and Houſe of Chocolate.

l.hi: Preſerve your Lambs from ſly Court Foxes.
From Love abroad, and none within doors.

sp.p: Good Morrow my Maſters all, Good Morrow: Paſt Twelve a Clock, and a warm Froſty Morning.—Ha! a Ladder at Mr. Deputies Back-window— Why, Sir, Mr. Deputy.—Your Houſe is broken open. Thieves, Thieves, Thieves.

div.stage: Enter Sir Dottrell, and Jacintha in her Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Thieves, Thieves, Thieves!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why 'tis I Child, Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sir Devil!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why, Chicken, I am come to Steal thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Steal me, Impudence! Thieves, Thieves, Thieves!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Deputy in his Night-Gown above.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.l: Ha! my Window broke open!—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, and your Houſe broke open! your Great Trunk broke open.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: My Great Trunk!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And your Cabinet of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: My Diamonds! Exit from above.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Why, Madam, what do you mean! What are you going to do! I hope you have more Conſcience than to ſerve me thus?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p:
Juſt as you deſerve, Mr. Thief—Here ſlip this Casket of Diamonds into your Pocket.
Giving a Casket to Palmerin.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Rob'd, ruin'd, undone! A Casket of Jewels bought of my Lord Squanderland for 6000 Pound, and worth 10000. Loſt, undone! ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, ſee there the Barbarous Thief.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Sir Dottrell. See there.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: You, Sir, Dottrell.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Yes, I Sir? what a Pox is't ſuch a wonderment to ſee an Old Rat in a young Mouſe-trap.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: I can't believe my Eyes.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: No, nor your Ears neither, if that young Witch has the handling of'em.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, Sir, yonder's my Lord Chief Juſtice come from Council at Whitehall, juſt turn'd the Corner o'th' Street in his Coach; what if I call him to hear the whole Buſineſs?

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: My Lord Chief Juſtice!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, let him be call'd, let me have Juſtice againſt that Barbarous Riffler of your Houſe. Now you may ſee how you've betray'd and ruin'd me. Made me diſpoſe my heart to that baſe Man. That came not hither for the Love of me. 'Twas not the Charms of all my Youth and Beauty; My blooming Virtue, and my Virgin Innocence.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Oh Woman, woman, woman!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No: 'twas the ſparkling Luſter of your Jewels that dazled in his Eyes.

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch a Traytreſs! Oh, Sir, believe her not one word; 'tis all Deſign, Plot, Treaſon, upon my Honour and my Life, Sir; and ſhe has no mercy than a Weaver at an Eaſt-India-Houſe. That wheedling diſſembling young Imp there told me ſhe had made a Vow to Marry no Man but he that ſhould ſteal her; and I like an old blind dunce—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Steal me! Bleſs my Ears! what ſays the Man! Steal me! Oh, Sir, Dottrell, Sir Dottrell, this is like the reſt of all your Barbarous Uſage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Ay, Child, ſteal thee!

sp.speaker: S. D.
sp.l: Ay Sir, ſteal her! I tell you, Sir, once more, that Monſter—

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p:
Ay, you may tell me what you pleaſe: You that can do ſuch wicked things, can have the confidence to ſay any thing.
Enter Palmerin as Lord Chief Juſtice, his Train born up by his Clark.
My Noble Lord! I beg your Lordſhips pardon for giving you this trouble at this unſeaſonable time of Night.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Juſtice is never troubleſome nor unſeaſonable, we are bound to right the injured.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Injur'd! Ay my Lord, I have had [A Chair ſet forth and Palm. ſits.] my Houſe broke open. I have been rob'd, my Lord, rob'd of a Casket of Jewels price 6000 l.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Six thouſand Pound!

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: See there the Ladder, and ſee here the Thief.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Sir Dottrell!

sp.speaker: S. Dot.
sp.p: I ſhall run mad; that's certain.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: The Worſhipful Sir Dottrell, I am all amazement.

sp.speaker: S. Dot.
sp.p: Amaz'd my Lord, Ay and amaz'd, and amaz'd again, when you have heard the whole Roguery. Your Lordſhip is a Good Man, and an Honourable man, and will do me Juſtice; I deſire you to hear me, my Lord; I'll tell you the whole truth from the Top to the Bottom. I'll confeſs all my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Confeſs! you can't do better Sir Dottrell.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: Then in the firſt place I am a wheizing, grunting, empty-headed old Sot of Fourſcore.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: In the next place, having no more Grace than Brains, and no more Fear before my Eyes than to—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Break open a Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: Break open a Houſe! No my Lord, break a fools head of my own, to run my reverend But-end a tilt at a Gay Petticoat, and play the old Game of hard heads call'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: Very well. Go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dot.
sp.p: An old doating fool to have no more ſenſe at theſe years than to pretend to make Womans Meat, when I am more fit for Worms-meat, my Lord. To be hankering after Young Fleſh, when I am going the way of all fleſh; and thus by the wicked inſtigation of the World, the Devil, and dry Bones, my Lord, with one Leg in my Grave I had no more Conſcience than think of ſlipping the other to Bed to a Girl of Nineteen; and to lay my old Froſt and Night-cap by her young Fruze and Top-knot.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And ſo falling in Love with a young Lady, and having a particular occaſion for a Necklace of Pearl, Locket of Diamonds, and ſome other Toys, to the Value of Six Thouſand Pounds, for a Preſent to your Young Miſtreſs, you made bold with Mr. Deputy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I know nothing of Mr. Deputy's Lockets and Diamonds. I had no Deſign but upon that precious Jewel his Daughter there; that young Fury with her Snakes in Powder and Curl; that Cloven-foot in Lac'd Shooes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Ha! What's all this?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: A wicked and notorious Jezabel, that has conſpir'd the Ruine, Fall and Deſtruction of the Right Worſhipful Sir Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Yet hold, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p:
I cannot hold. I muſt confeſs my Sins, and repent, my Lord; and tell your Lordſhip, I have been galloping Headlong in the fair Road to the Devil, my Lord. For an Old Coxcomb of Eighty Eight, that has no more Wit than to Marry a Young Girl of Eighteen, heaps more Coals upon his Head
than another City Conflagration; and ought to be Marry'd on no Day but the Second of September, my Lord. For when the Firebrands of Whoredom and Cuckoldom are once lighted, they are unquencheable; and a Young Gipſie that takes Fire in her Pudding-Lane, is never to be ſtopt till ſhe burns down to Bridewell, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: How now! Ill-manner'd, Sir! Do you know where you are? This Inſolence before the Bar of Juſtice! Ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhip's Pardon.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Better Language, and more Civility.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I have done, Sir. I know no Harm of the poor Girl. She is a Good Girl, and an Honeſt Girl, and a Religious Girl— Why, I have heard her at her Prayers, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: No more trifling, Sir. If you have any thing to ſay, ſpeak home to the purpoſe. Has this young Lady done you any Wrong any Injuſtice, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Wrong! O Lord, no! She has done me a great deal of Right, my Lord. Alas, Sir, I have been an impertinent Old Fool, and have ſo tired and teized her, and haunted her, till the poor Thing, in her own Defence, when I would take no Warning, and receive no denial, has only drawn me into a Plot, Sir; to ſee my Back-ſide, Sir; to get a fair Riddance of me, by ſending me up High Holborn, and pleaſe your Lordſhip: I vow and ſwear that's all.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And did ſhe draw you into this Plot?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: She, Sir; Ay, ay. Why, I broke open her Father's Houſe by her own Special Command.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Very pretty! And ſo in Obedience to a fair Lady—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: To rid her of a troubleſom old Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You committed Burglary.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Very true, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: In pure Complaiſance to be hang'd out of the way.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, if that Falſe Peacher can Swear me or Lie me into a Halter, I ſhall be hang'd and hang'd, and double hang'd, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Oh, I have heard too much a plain Confeſſion: Dead, gone, loſt!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Dead, Sir!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: The World can't ſave ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! Not ſave me!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Impoſſible! Oh Sir Dottrel, Sir Dottrel! A Man of your Eſtate, a Perſon of your Worth, for you to run yourſelf into this hideous Sin— Oh, 'tis unpardonable! A Common Thief! Poor Rogues, that break a Houſe for want, for Bread for Hunger, thoſe pitied Wretches might find ſome Beams of Grace: But you, Sir Dottrel; Oh, there's no Hopes, no Mercy!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir? I hope you don't intend to hang me.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Had you a Thouſand Lives, all, all loſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, my Dear Lord, don't fright me! Hang an Alderman! Hang a Gold Chain! I ſhall never be able to bear it. Oh, my dear Lord, upon my Knees I do beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Kneel, Sir, to Heaven, not me; make your Peace there, Sir Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, don't talk of Heaven! I tremble at the Name on't. And, Madam, dear Madam, ſave me, ſave me. Dear Honey, ſweet Devil, ſpeak Truth but this once in thy whole Life, and tell my Lord the whole Story. Dear Rogue, don't let me be hang'd: Beſides, I ſhall make but a ſneaking Dog in a String; and thou'lt get no Credit by Hanging me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Nay; why do you trouble me?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I'll never trouble thee again: I'll quit thee, reſign thee, renounce thee for ever. And therefore, ſweet little Tygreſs, ſpeak a good Word to my Lord: Save but my Life, and I'll give thee half my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Dote.
sp.p: Half my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: My Lord, do you hear how the poor Man begs for Life? If your Lordſhip can do any thing for him—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Do you deſire it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, ſhe does deſire it; ſhe muſt deſire it.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: Nay, Madam, your Commands—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: O ſweet Rogue!

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Well, Sir Dottrel, for this fair Lady's ſake I'll try what I can do for you. But fie, Sir Dottrel, half your Eſtate! That's too much: You ſhall have Mercy at a cheaper Price.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Oh, you're a good Man.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: But firſt, Sir Dottrel, have not you an Eſtate of young Palmerin Worthy's, bought of his Prodigal Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: And I warrant you, did not give half the Worth ſor't.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Not a Quarter.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Then upon Condition that, before all theſe Witneſſes, you'll give it under your Hand and Seal, to return that Eſtate to young Palmerin, I'll promiſe you your Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Here's my Clark then ſhall draw up the Agreement.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, my Lord, you ſhall have it under Hand, Seal, Bill, Bond, Judgment, Statute; any thing for a ſweet Life, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Well now, Sir Dottrel, I hope I am not that hard hearted Thing; you ſee I am all Tenderneſs, all melting Pity; ſo very kind—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Kind! Ay, Pox on thee, thou'rt damnable kind!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Heav'ns bleſs thee, I would ſay. Kind Chicken! Ay, very kind; a dear ſweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Come, Sir Dottrel, your Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Ay, both my Hands. Signs and Seals.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: You deliver this as your Act and Deed to the Uſe of Palmerin Worthy.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: To the Uſe of Palmerin VVorthy.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: So; now to perform my Part. In the firſt place, Mr. Deputy, to make Peaee with you, Sir Dottrel heartily begs your Pardon, and by my Hand reſtores your Jewels, [gives Mr. Deputy the Casket.] In the next place, to remove all Fears and Jealouſies of a Bench and Judges; inſtead of that terrible thing call'd a Lord Chief Juſtiee, I am that harmleſs poor Creature, your Honeſt Man Shackarell.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p:
No; no Shackarell neither: For inſtead of your Man Shakarell, I am
your Rival Palmarin; no more yours, but this Lady's Humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.l: And now, Mr. Deputy—

sp.speaker: Pal.
sp.p: As kind Fortune has at laſt removed all Obſtacles to my Honourable Pretenſions to the Fair Jacintha; as this kind Knight has given me one Eſtate, I hope you'll give me another, your Beautiful Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Ay, with all my Heart and Soul. Take her, dear Boy, take her, and Heav'n bleſs thee with her. Young Palmerin, and a Thouſand a Year! Thou art ſuch an ingenious young Rogue, thou deſervd'ſt a Girl with her Weight in Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Here's fine Work.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Go, take her to Church, take her to thy Arms, take her to Bed; and get me Grandſons and Great Grandſons. How ſhall I mend my dull City-Breed with ſuch a Wit for my Son-in-law!

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And art not thou a Perjur'd Devil?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Perjur'd! No, not at all.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: No, young Deceiver? Where's the Promiſe you made me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: I have perform'd 'em.
Yes, Sir; I promis'd ye before this Honeſt Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Honeſt with a Vengeance!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Sir Dottrel was the Man of the whole World
Should make me the happieſt and beſt Wife in Chriſtendom,
And I have kept that Promiſe: For Sir Dottrel
Has given my Palmerin an Eſtate, and that
Eſtate has given me Palmerin. And thus
(Upon my Knees I thank you.) You have made me
That beſt, that happieſt Wife—

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: I can bear no longer. Going away.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yet, ſtay, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: Stay, Tormenter!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Ay, Sir; ſtay—I have a Boon to ask you.
That you'd forgive me.
Ay, Sir; forgive me: Do. I beg it of you.
I own my Faults; own I have us'd you hardly.
And yet I never wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: How! Not wrong'd me!

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: No, Sir; not wrong'd you: I have lov'd ye more
In cheating you, than marrying you. Conſider
What 'twas you ask'd; and what I have deny'd.
Marriage, alas! Sir Dottrell, had undone ye:
To take a Wife, were that Rack Rent upon ye▪
Your Age could never pay. Let ſuch Grey Hairs
Go not to Church to Wedlock, but to Prayers,
And kneel to Heaven, not Woman, at thoſe years.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: In troth, thou art in the right on't. I confeſs.
In thy ſoft Arms I ſhould have ſlept ſo ſweetly—
And Sleeping had been all; nay, and, perhaps, not that too.
I ſhould have ſpit, and cough'd, and wheiz'd, and grunted;
Made but a ſlovenly Husband for a young Wife.
And therefore, Palmerin, give me thy Hand—
And thine, Jacintha— Now, if I could but out with it—

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Speak boldly.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Reſign me nobly.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Do a generous Deed.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: And think what Glorious Triumph you will make:
'Tis brave to give, when it is poor to take.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Then take her, and be happy— But, I vow,
It almoſt breaks my Heart, that I muſt loſe thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Nay, dry your Eyes. I will do more than love ye.
What though I cannot give a Hand, (for that's
My Palmerin's;) I'll give you both my Knees.
I'll pray for you to my laſt Hour of Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.p: And wilt thou pray for me?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: More than a Father.
He gave me Birth: But you have given me Palmerin.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Yes, thou ſhalt pray for me: For I'll do ſomething
As ſhall deſerve thy Prayers. Here, Palmerin;
To thy own Eſtate, I have given thee, take mine too.
For, ſince I muſt not make my dear Jacintha
My Wife, my Heir I'll make thee. No Old Age,
Nor no Young Rival ſhall debar me that.
My Fortunes, Treaſures, Jewels: Five fair Lordſhips;
Twice five fair Thouſand Acres;
And thrice as many Pounds in fairer Gold,
Is all thy own. Give but a poor Old Man
My Length and Breadth in Clay, when I am Duſt;
And all the reſt, my dear Jacintha, 's thine.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.l: Oh, this amazing Kindneſs! Let me kneel once more:
Too poor in Thanks to pay this wondrous Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Palm.
sp.p: Too poor, indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Nay, fye; dear Shackarel, riſe.
Thou art the happy Lord of fair Jacintha,
And I am thy Servant now— And riſe Jacintha, riſe.
Come, Mr. Deputy; we'll both be Fathers now.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dep.
sp.p: Yes, I the happieſt, you the kindeſt Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Dott.
sp.l: Come, thou ſweet Bride that muſt be, we'll prepare
The Wedding-Dinner: Shall we not?
We'll have the Poets, and the Fiddles too,
And all the Wedding Joys. I ſhall be pleas'd
To ſee young Palmerin the happy Man:
Nay, I'll dance too, as heartily as I can. Exeunt.

div.stage: Being a Proſpect of Terras Walks on Eight ſeveral Stages mounted one above another, each Stage contains a Range of Stone-work extending from ſide to ſide, decorated with Paintings in Freſco of Heroick Hiſtory; over each Piece of Painting are carved Rails and Baniſters with Pedeſtals: On Thirty Two Pedeſtals are planted Sixteen Golden Flower-Pots, and Sixteen Statues of Gods and Goddeſſes, viz. Jupiter and Juno; Apollo and Diana; Mars and Venus; Neptune and Thetis; Pallas and Mercury; Bacchus and Ceres; Hercules and Flora; Cupid and Pſyche. Through the Center, and advancing Twenty Four Foot high, is an Aſcent of Marble Steps. This Sett of Scenes is encompaſs'd round with Arborage-work, circled round with double Feſtoons of Flowers tyed up in Ribbons of Gold, terminating at Fifty Foot deep, being the Extent of the Houſe, with a Proſpect of a Garden above the higheſt Terras.
Above Fifty Figures are ſeen upon the ſeveral Terras's, ſome of which Deſcend upon the Stage for the Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Croſs,
sp.l: COme Strephon, Phyllis come let's troll
A Jovial Hour away.
And whilſt the Golden Minutes roll,
We'll Sing and Dance, and Play.

sp.speaker: Miſs.
sp.l: See in the ſmiling Month of May,
The Songſters of the Grove they play,
Muſt ſuch a poor young thing as they
A little Bird ſo very ſmall
That juſt can tattle, chirp and prattle:
I can but ſing, and Oh that's all.
But if I live till paſt fifteen,
See ſuch fine Sparks as here are ſeen.
I fear, I fear, you'l teach me then
To perch and plume, and dreſs and pride,
And more than tattle,
Chirp and prattle,
I then ſhall ſing and love beſide.
Let Monarchs boaſt their High Renown;
A Garland's fairer than a Crown.
Whilſt Courts have all the Pomp and noiſe,
The Groves have all the Sweets and Joys.
Then come kind Damon, come away,
To Cynthia's Bower advance;
The Sylvanes they ſhall Pipe and Play,
And we'll lead up the Dance.

lg.l: Hark, hark! To Pleaſure and Delight
The Earth, the Seas, and Air invite:
The Winds, they whiſtle; Woods, they ring;
The Brooks, they murmur; Birds, they ſing:
The Turtles coo; and Lambs, they play:
And why not we at blithe as they?
Then, whilſt we trip it o'er o'er the Plain,
Let Pan and Flora live and reign:
We'll envy not great Jove; and be
As bleſs'd, though not as great as He.
But, ſee! Our Goddeſs does appear!
She comes to grace our Rural Choir:
Then let the Muſes all inſpire
Our Joys to a Sublimer Air.
Let her Great Name go round;
Yet louder let it ſound.
Cynthia! a Name ſo proud,
To chant her endleſs Song,
Jove's Thunder's not too loud;
Eternity too long.

sp.speaker: Grand Chorus,
sp.l: Let her Great Name, &c.

sp.speaker: Hains.
sp.p: Well, Sir; and what think you of our New World in the Moon?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, Faith, Jo, I think, as your Painter has dreſs'd it, 'tis a new World indeed.
And how do you like it?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.l: As I do a Miſtreſs the better for being a new one.
New Objects ſtill new Appetites muſt raiſe,
And an Original Beauty ſure may pleaſe.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
div.byline: Spoke by Miſs Dennis Chock, Dreſs'd with a great Wig like a Beau.
div.stage: She Enters Singing Part of an Old Tune.

sp.l: THE Author ſends me here, to win your Hearts
VVith this full VVig, and not his own Deſerts;
For he believes, and I ſuppoſe you know,
There's nothing pleaſes more than a young Beau.
But yet the Stage this day has done its best;
For it has furniſh'd out a Miſer's Feaſt:
And if this Charge and Pains ſhould now be lost,
'Twere hard to Shipwrack on a Golden Coast.
But, Gentlemen and Ladies, I muſt ſay,
Since I am choſe Champion to defend this Play,
I'll do't: Draws her Sword.
And here, with Sword in Hand, declare
To juſtifie it, againſt all that dare
Strive to undo the Painter, and the Player.
The Poet, he, alas! only depends
On your Good Nature, to become his Friends.
But now, perhaps, you may believe I fear
To ſee this naked Weapon. But I ſwear
I'd fight our Foes, did I not too well know
'Twould ſpoil my Character of being a Beau.
Therefore, ſince I'm good natur'd, be you kind;
For, rat me, Gentlemen, 'twas well deſign'd.
But, Pax upon 'em, 'tis all home-ſpun Cloth;
All from an Engliſh Web, and Engliſh Growth.
But if we'd let it make a coſtly Dance
To Paris, and bring home ſome Scenes from France,
I'm ſure 'twou'd take: For you, Gadzooks, are civil;
And wiſh them well, that wiſh you at the Devil.
